image.altText: A teen girl with her arm around her grandfather looking at each other, standing in front of a light aircraft

props.synopsis: Teenager Alicia Hayes fell in love with flying at the age of seven after a flight with her grandfather. Now, she's prepping to be the youngest pilot at the Aldinga Airshow in South Australia this weekend.

title.children: 'We're like peas and carrots': Alicia and her grandfather share close bond over aviation

image.altText: A yoga instructor and participant.

props.synopsis: Yoga has long been thought of as a method for flexibility, but it also emphasises inclusivity, with participants pointing out that the practice can be noticeably different from the way it is sometimes portrayed on social media.

title.children: Yoga is about much more than what you might see on Instagram, participants say

image.altText: A vehicle burning and emitting black smoke as trucks were banked up on a road among scrubland

props.synopsis: Three men are dead after a road train and a truck collided on the Eyre Highway, about 27 kilometres west of Yalata, on South Australia's west coast.

title.children: Three die in highway crash involving two trucks in South Australia

image.altText: Australian and Aboriginal flying flags side-by-side.

props.synopsis: A mother who requested her children be allowed to "sit silently" during the national anthem claims one was given detention by a private Christian school for refusing to stand.

title.children: Mother removes Aboriginal children from school following 'ultimatum' on standing for national anthem

image.altText: Joe Biden sits in front of Israeli and American flags. He is speaking.

props.synopsis: US President Joe Biden and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speak, days after an IDF strike killed aid workers — including an Australian — delivering food in Gaza.

title.children: Biden threatens change in US policy if Netanyahu fails to protect civilians in Gaza

image.altText: Afsoun Rastegari wearing large headphones and looking into the camera while waiting at a train station.

props.synopsis: Employers are stepping up their game to entice staff back into the office. But, not all perks are created equal, with some — like offering a longer holiday — proving more effective than others.

title.children: Companies are trying to convince staff to stop working from home, and the office perks are getting creative

image.altText: Aerial photograph of planes parked at airport gates.

props.synopsis: Airlines make most of their profits from air travel, right? Turns out, much of the value of these companies comes from operating in the financial realm.

title.children: Money for nothing: How airlines are making billions out of loyalty programs

image.altText: Bob Iger points at the camera wearing a suit while standing next to Emily Blunt in a white puff dress on the red carpet.

props.synopsis: A years-long stand-off between two men over the future of Disney has finally come to an end. This is what we know about how chief executive Bob Iger vanquished investor Nelson Peltz.

title.children: Disney's astonishingly well-paid CEO has vanquished his rival. But a succession drama still looms

image.altText: Weather signs, wet roads and cars

props.synopsis: Torrential rain across New South Wales and Queensland brings weather and wind warnings, raising concerns over flooding between the Blue Mountains and Narooma.

title.children: 100mm of rain in Sydney CBD, flood warnings across NSW as torrential rain hits east coast

image.altText: SES volunteers stand at silver ute in brown rushing water near Mullumbimby in northern NSW

props.synopsis: Premier Chris Minns gives update on the wet weather response as Sydney was hit with the most rainfall overnight. Follow live.

title.children: Drivers told to avoid unnecessary trips in rain-affected NSW as 'significant weather event' unfolds

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Warragamba Dam likely to spill Monday
Avoid unnecessary driving trips, SES Commissioner says

image.altText: A young white girl with blonde hair yawns while holding a book at daycare in Broken Hill.

props.synopsis: Heather Pearce always had trouble attracting qualified professionals to her Broken Hill medical practice for long-term roles— until she made sure their kids had child care.

title.children: Outback businesswoman opens childcare centre for her staff's kids, with ripples felt throughout the community

image.altText: A mother wraps her arms around her daughter. Both look solemn.

props.synopsis: Year 9 students at Renmark High School allege that references to bestiality were made during a third-party presentation on "respectful relationships" that was not supervised by a teacher.

title.children: High school investigating alleged bestiality references in presentation to girls

image.altText: Pickett1

props.synopsis: Star small forward Kysaiah Pickett is set to face scrutiny for a high bump on Jake Soligo, as the Demons kept the Crows winless to start Gather Round.

title.children: Demons livewire Pickett to face scrutiny over bump as winless season continues for Crows

image.altText: A man in a suit walks away from a court building, with camera operators behind him.

props.synopsis: Former Seven Network producer Taylor Auerbach will today return to the Federal Court witness box to give a second day of evidence in former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann's defamation case.

title.children: Former Seven producer Taylor Auerbach to give second day of evidence in Bruce Lehrmann defamation

image.altText: Ryan Gury at a drone racing event

props.synopsis: A small community of hobby drone racers, chasing a need for speed, unintentionally made a "terrifyingly powerful" weapon that has changed the world.

title.children: Ryan was building the fastest racing drones in the world. And then the military called

image.altText: José Andrés sits in front of a blue screen that says 'Clinton Global Initiative'. He holds his hands out as he speaks.

props.synopsis: Washington's powerful denizens regularly dine at José Andrés's restaurants, but it's his humanitarian work that's earned him real respect and influence. And now, he's heartbroken and furious.

title.children: This celebrity chef is a DC legend. Could Israel killing his aid workers push Washington to change course?

image.altText: Three day measles infection

props.synopsis: Health authorities have issued a second measles alert for a range of locations in Adelaide after a teenager tested positive.

title.children: SA Health releases exposure sites after teenager tests positive to measles

image.altText: Malls Balls in Rundle Mall.

props.synopsis: A police crackdown in Adelaide's CBD has netted 48 people for shoplifting offences and recovered about $7,000 worth of allegedly stolen items in a single day.

title.children: Dozens arrested or reported in one day during shoplifting sting in Adelaide's CBD

image.altText: Satellite image of three cars on coastal road.

props.synopsis: A group of international experts analysed images and geolocations of wreckages to offer their views on the deadly Gaza aid convoy strike, which Israel claims was "unintentional", blaming it on "misidentification".

title.children: Israel says deadly Gaza aid convoy strike was a 'grave mistake', but experts say the images tell a different story

image.altText: Police walking in the Alice Springs CBD.

props.synopsis: The Alice Springs tourism sector is calling for an urgent federal support package as some operators report their "worst Easter ever".

title.children: As the Alice Springs youth curfew continues, tourism operators are 'at breaking point'

image.altText: Linda Baumann and her grandson Connor sit next to each other on a park bench. They're both smiling and happy.

props.synopsis: RSV vaccines are available for Australians for the first time this winter, but depending on what state you live in access may be limited. Linda Baumann battled the virus and knows just how fast it can take hold.

title.children: RSV vaccines are here in time for winter flu season – but not everyone is eligible

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly News Quiz: Australia's new governor-general, a royal easter appearance and a python's odd snack

image.altText: Collage photo of Willie Nelson, Paul McCartney, Miley Cyrus, Beyonce, Pharrell Williams, Nile Rodgers and Dolly Parton

props.synopsis: The guest list for Beyoncé's new album is a mixture of country heroes, emerging hip hop stars, and some of her closest and most famous regular collaborators.

title.children: Cowboy Carter came together with a little help from Beyoncé's many friends

image.altText: A man sits at a desk surrounded by computer screens. Two rows of screens overhead show stocks.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is set to open firmly in the red, as US stocks drop after Federal Reserve officials suggest rate cuts may come later this year, or even next. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to slide as Wall Street drops on Fed rate fears

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Sea of red as the ASX opens
Armaguard says it will keep carrying cash … if it can keep more of it
Israel-Iran tensions driving oil up and shares lower

image.altText: A woman sits with her head in her hands at a table surrounded by bills

props.synopsis: The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services will look at existing laws, the possible role of banks, and public awareness of what is considered a more hidden form of family and domestic violence.

title.children: 'I'm still in survival mode': Lily was destroyed by economic abuse, and says her bank could have done more

image.altText: Graham Quirk talking to ABC newsreader Jessica van Vonderen

props.synopsis: Graham Quirk reveals a conversation with International Committee member John Coates about the debate tarnishing the Games.

title.children: Two men, two starkly different ideas for Brisbane's Olympics — but there's one thing they agree on

image.altText: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory senator says youth crime in the Alice and other parts of NT has risen due to the circumstances children are being brought up in.

title.children: Price concerned NT could become a 'lockdown territory' due to wave of youth crime

image.altText: A woman named Kristine Meakins carries a little girl while two boys stand in front of her.

props.synopsis: Perth's housing crisis shows no signs of easing, and for one young family of five it means living in a tent is their only option.

title.children: When Kristine's house burnt down she had nowhere to go. She and her four children now live in a tent

props.synopsis: The Coalition have clearly decided they are backing the Israeli government all the way. But this has left them seemingly unable to condemn actions that led to the death of an Australian aid worker.

title.children: Angus Taylor ties himself in knots over an airstrike as the Coalition tethers itself to Israel

image.altText: Man with black shirt and necklace sits on couch behind yellow wall

props.synopsis: One of the faces of the unsuccessful Yes campaign for an Indigenous Voice to Parliament, Thomas Mayo reflects on a "gut-wrenching" referendum loss and personal attacks against him.

title.children: 'Gut-wrenching': Thomas Mayo reflects on failed Voice campaign six months after referendum

image.altText: A crowd of people fill of young kids and adults wearing white helmets

props.synopsis: Western Australian Labor MP Tania Lawrence, and Brisbane-native Peter Dunstan were in Taiwan when an earthquake hit. They say the shaking was aggressive and the strongest ever felt.

title.children: Australians in Taiwan during the earthquake recount moments of 'violent' shaking and noise

image.altText: Cheese sits on shelves in the factor.

props.synopsis: Australian consumers are buying more artisanal varieties as the price of a block of grocery store cheese reaches a two-year high.

title.children: Australian cheese lovers paying too much for cheddar turn to vegan and artisanal varieties

image.altText: An illustration of Edward Henty and other settlers with large barrels, guns and livestock on a beach.

props.synopsis: Hearings at Victoria's Yoorrook Justice Commission have shone a light on the violence that underpinned the state's colonisation in the 1830s, truths the commission hopes will pave the way to a more mature understanding of Victoria's past and present.

title.children: Why the British came to see the rapid and deadly settlement of Victoria as 'a disaster they couldn't control'

image.altText: a blonde woman wearing all black sitting at a desk with bookshelves filled with books and plants behind her

props.synopsis: Lauren has a unique problem. Her attic is producing an endless supply of husbands. That's the set-up of a new novel called The Husbands by Australian author Holly Gramazio, who says she wouldn't have picked her own husband if she'd encountered him online.

title.children: Author of The Husbands wouldn't have chosen hers if she'd seen his dating profile — which proves her point
